name: HTML
description: No matter what you do you can't avoid this language. Semantic HTML is something important to try to utilize for SEO and helping the visually impaired.

card.title: Semantic HTML
card.subTitle: My resource
card.description: This is a great resource to understand which elements you can and can't use.

name: CSS
description: This language is a struggle. Flexbox and grid are extremely helpful and CSS frameworks make responsivity easier, learning their grid system is key.

card.title: You Need This.
card.subTitle: CSS Transitions
card.description: This is one of those things that you just need to learn. While you can never completely master CSS (people on codepen aren't human) being able to utilize this is huge for your application

card.title: CSS Frameworks
card.subTitle: Love them and hate them
card.description: Bootstrap was the first framework that I got in to just because I heard the name a lot. At first the framework seemed magical, but I later realized that these frameworks have their downfall and learning vanilla CSS was a big win for me.

name: JavaScript
description: I'm actually in love with Javascript. This is the first langauge where I felt like I was actually coding (higher order functions and promises). Javascript is a meeting ground for developers and will always hold a special place in my heart

card.title: There are a lot of functions.
card.subTitle: MDN to the rescue!
card.description: The thing I like most about JavaScript is that the best way to learn is to build with it. If you run in to a comming thing you need to do there's usually a built in method for that (ES6 is especially useful).

card.title: You-Dont-Know-JS
card.subTitle: More understanding
card.description: I'm currently going through the series and think it's a good resource for anyone looking to learn more about JavaScript. Understanding what is actually going on in JavaScript is weird, but ultimately helps your understanding.

name: Vue.js
description: Vue is amazing. Their documentation is intuitive and it's sleek enough to get the job done, without all the extras you usually won't need

card.title: Check out their docs!
card.subTitle: Their docs are what got me
card.description: After learning dom manipulation going in to a framework that does the work for you, but also requires you to use javascript logic is a nice feeling. Vue with webpack is very modular and has most of what you need to create a SPA (if not they have something for it you can add).

card.title: Vuex
card.subTitle: Even if you don't need it, it's tempting to use.
card.description: Vuex makes it possible to have centralized state mangement. I actually had a unique opportunity to look at Vuex in actions and was able to soak in the modularity required and how cool this actually is.

name: Node.js
description: Having an environment where you can use a language you already know, and is a meeting ground for developers is very intuitive.

card.title: This one was tricky.
card.subTitle: Javascript on the back-end???
card.description: Since it's obvious how JavaScript is the meeting ground for developers being able to transfer that(with some caveats) makes your site very uniform.

name: Express
description: This Node.js web application framework works extremely well with Knex and make Full Stack Development easier.

card.title: Another framework?
card.subTitle: Meant for Node.js
card.description: This 'module framework' lets you listen for input/connect requests from clients. This works extremely well with Knex's queries.

name: Git
description: I use git for version control, it's one of the things that you just need.

card.title: Freen and Open source
card.subTitle: Saves your life
card.description: This is probably one of the things that I've had the most experience with.

name: Github
description: What I use (and mostly everybody else)

card.title: My account
card.subTitle: Not overwhelming
card.description: Most of the work that I've done has been in private repositorys, but I'm still looking to contribute to open source projects.

card.title: What I use.
card.subTitle: heroku logs --tail
card.description: The logs are actually good, and it makes it easy to debug.

name: Postgresql
description: The world's most advanced open source database.

card.title: Needs no introduction
card.subTitle: Written in C
card.description: Works well with the tools I use.

name: Mocha
description: I use mocha chai and supertest

card.title: Great Resource
card.subTitle: This was one of my old instructors and he has a really good video on this.
card.description: Makes it easy to test and make sure everything is working.
